questions.question: What is JavaScript?
options: A. A markup language
B. A programming language
C. A database management system
D. A networking protocol

questions.question: What are the data types supported by JavaScript?
options: A. String, number, boolean
B. Object, array, null
C. Undefined, function, symbol
D. All of the above

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'typeof' operator in JavaScript?
options: A. To check if a variable is defined
B. To determine the data type of a value
C. To compare two values for equality
D. To declare a new variable
questions.answer: B. To determine the data type of a value

questions.question: What is the difference between 'null' and 'undefined' in JavaScript?
options: A. 'null' represents an empty string, while 'undefined' represents a missing value
B. 'null' is a data type, while 'undefined' is a keyword
C. 'null' represents intentional absence of any object value, while 'undefined' represents absence of a value
D. 'null' and 'undefined' are interchangeable in JavaScript
questions.answer: C. 'null' represents intentional absence of any object value, while 'undefined' represents absence of a value

questions.question: What is an anonymous function in JavaScript?
options: A. A function that is not used in the code
B. A function without a return statement
C. A function that does not have a name
D. A function that is used for debugging purposes
questions.answer: C. A function that does not have a name

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'this' keyword in JavaScript?
options: A. To refer to the current object
B. To declare a new variable
C. To create a loop in JavaScript
D. To comment out a block of code
questions.answer: A. To refer to the current object

questions.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?
options: A. A way to store data in a file
B. A syntax error in JavaScript
C. A function that executes immediately
D. A function that has access to its own scope and the scope of the outer function
questions.answer: D. A function that has access to its own scope and the scope of the outer function

questions.question: What is the difference between '==' and '===' in JavaScript?
options: A. '==' performs type coercion, while '===' does not
B. '==' checks for equality of both value and type, while '===' only checks for equality of value
C. '==' and '===' are interchangeable in JavaScript
D. '==' is used for arithmetic operations, while '===' is used for string operations
questions.answer: A. '==' performs type coercion, while '===' does not

questions.question: What are the different ways to create objects in JavaScript?
options: A. Using object literals
B. Using constructor functions
C. Using the 'Object.create()' method
D. All of the above

questions.question: What is event delegation in JavaScript?
options: A. The process of assigning events to HTML elements
B. A technique for handling events on dynamically created elements
C. The process of bubbling events up the DOM tree
D. A method for attaching event listeners to specific elements
questions.answer: B. A technique for handling events on dynamically created elements
